children.text: 1.  Understand numbers, ways of representing numbers, relationships among numbers and number systems
A. Read, write and compare numbers
rote counts to 100 (ST MA 1,6  1.6, 1.10) (FR V.1.d, X.a)
recognizes "how many" in a set of objects (ST MA 1,6  1.10)(FR V.d, X.a)
read, write and compare whole numbers less than 100 (ST MA 1   1.10)(FR V.d)
read, write and compare  whole numbers up to 3 digits (ST MA  1 1.10)(FR V.d)
read, write and compare decimals to the hundredths place and whole numbers up to 6 digits (MA 5 1.10)(FR V.d)
read, write, compare and order unit fractions and decimals to thousandths (ST MA 5  3.3)(FR IX.b)
compare and order integers, positive rationals and percents, including finding their approximate location on a number line (ST MA 5   3.3)(FR IX.b)
compare and order integers, positive rationals and percents, including finding their approximate location on a number line (ST MA 5  3.3)(FR IX.b)
compare and order rationals and percents, including finding their approximate locations on a number line (ST MA 5  3.3)(FR IX.b)
compare and order rational and irrational numbers, including finding their approximate locations on a number line (ST MA 5  3.3)(FR IX.a)
B. Represent and use rational numbers
recognize 1/2, 1/3 and 1/4 of a shape (ST MA 1  1.10)(FR V.c)
represents commonly used fractions: halves, thirds and fourths (ST MA 1  1.10)(FR V.c, V.i)
use models, benchmarks (0, 1/2 and 1) and equivalent forms to judge the size of fractions (ST MA 1   3.3)(FR V.c, V.i)
recognize and generate equivalent forms of commonly used fractions, decimals and percents (ST MA 1   3.3)(FR V.b)
recognize and generate equivalent forms of fractions, decimals and percents (ST MA 1  3.3)(FR V.b)
use fractions, decimals and percents to solve problems (ST MA 1  3.4)(FR V.d)
use fractions, decimals and percents to solve problems  (ST MA 1  3.4)(FR V.d)
use real numbers to solve problems (ST MA 1  3.4)(FR V.1.a)
C. Compose and decompose numbers
connect number words (orally) and quantities they represent (ST MA 1  1.10) (FR V.c)
compose or decompose numbers using known facts, doubles and close to doubles (ST MA 1  3.2,3.3)(FR V.e)
compose or decompose  numbers by using a variety of strategies, such as using  known facts, tens or landmark numbers to solve problems (ST MA 1  3.2,3.3)(FR V.e)
recognize equivalent representations for the same number and generate them by decomposing and composing numbers (ST MA 1  3.6)(FR V.e)
recognize equivalent representations for the same number and generate them by decomposing and composing numbers (ST MA 1  3.6)(FR V.e)
recognize equivalent representations for the same number and generate them by decomposing and composing numbers (ST MA 1  3.6)(FR V.b)
recognize equivalent representations for the same number and generate them by decomposing and composing numbers, including expanded notation (ST MA 1  3.6)(FR V.b)
recognize equivalent representations for the same number and generate them by decomposing and composing numbers, including exponential notation (ST MA 1  3.6)(FR V.b)
recognize equivalent representations for the same number and generate them by decomposing and composing numbers, including scientific notation (ST MA 1  3.6)(FR V.b)
use a variety of representations to demonstrate an understanding of very large  and very small numbers (ST MA 5  3.6)(FR IX.a & d)
use vectors and matrices as systems and compare their properties to the real-number system (ST MA 5)(FR IX.a & d)
D. Classify and describe numeric relationships
skip count by 2s, 5s and 10s  (ST MA 1  1.10)(FR V.1.d)
classify numbers by their characteristics, including odd and even  (ST MA 1  1.10)(FR V.e)
classify and describe numbers by their characteristics, including odd, even and multiples (ST MA 1  1.10)(FR V.e, IX.d)
describe numbers according to their characteristics, including whole number factors, prime or composite, odd or even and square numbers (ST MA 5  1.10)(FR IX.c)
use factors and multiples to describe relationships between and among numbers,  including whole number common factors and multiples  (ST MA 5  1.10)(FR IX.c)
use whole number factors and multiples to describe relationships between and among numbers (ST MA 5 1.10)(FR IX.c)
use factors and multiples to describe relationships between and among numbers and justify characteristics of numbers (ST MA 5 1.10)(FR IX.c)
2.  Understand meanings of operations and how they relate to one another
A. Represent operations
represent a given situation involving addition (ST MA 1  1.6,1.10)(FR V.a)
represent a given situation involving addition or subtraction (ST MA 1  1.6,1.10)(FR V.a)
represent a given situation involving multiplication (ST MA 1  1.6,1.10)(FR V.a)
read, write and compare decimals to the hundredths place and whole numbers up to 6 digits (ST MA 5   1.10)(FR IX.b)
represent and recognize multiplication using various models, including sets and arrays (ST MA 1  3.6)(FR V.a)
represent and recognize division using various models, including quotative and partitive (ST MA 1  3.6)
B. Describe effects of operations
describe the effects of adding and subtracting whole numbers as well as the relationship between the two operations (ST MA 1  3.4,4.1)(FR V.e)
describe the effects of multiplying and dividing whole numbers as well as the relationship between the two operations (ST MA 5  3.4,4.1)(FR IX.e & c)
describe the effects of addition and subtraction on fractions and decimals (ST MA 1, 5  3.4,4.1)(FR V.a, IX.a)
describe the effects of multiplication and division on fractions and addition and subtraction on integers (ST MA 1  3.4,4.1)(FR V.a)
describe the effects of multiplication and division on integers (ST MA 1  3.4,4.1)(FR V.a)
describe the effects of operations, such as multiplication, division, and computing powers and roots on the magnitude of quantities (ST MA 4  3.4,4.1)(FR VIII.i)
C. Apply properties of operations
apply commutative and identity  properties of addition to whole numbers (ST MA 5 1.6,1.10)(FR IX.c)
apply commutative and identity properties of multiplication to whole numbers (ST MA 5  1.6,1.10)(FR IX.c)
apply the distributive and associative properties to whole numbers (ST MA 5  1.6,1.10)(FR IX.e)
apply properties of operations (including order of operations) to positive rational numbers  (ST MA 5 1.6,1.10)(FR IX.e)
apply properties of operations to rational numbers, including order of operations and inverse operations (ST MA 5  1.6,1.10)(FR IX.e)
apply properties of exponents (including order of operations) to simplify expressions (ST MA 4  1.6,1.10)(FR VIII.c & d)
apply properties of exponents to simplify expressions or solve equations (ST MA 4  1.6,1.10)(FR VIII.c & d)
apply properties of logarithms to simplify expressions or solve equations (ST MA 4  1.6,1.10)(FR VIII.c & d)
apply properties of functions to simplify expressions or solve equations (ST MA 4,5  1.6,1.10)(FR VIII.c & d, IX.b)
D. Apply operations on real and complex numbers
approximate the value of square roots to the nearest whole number (ST MA 5  3.3)(FR IX.f)
apply the relationship between squares and square roots and cubes and cube roots to solve a problem (ST MA 5  1.6,3.4)(FR IX.f)
apply operations to real numbers, using mental computation or paper-and-pencil calculations for simple cases and technology for more complicated cases (ST MA 1,4,5 1.4,3.4)(FR V.a, VIII.d, IX.6)
apply operations to real numbers, using mental computation or paper-and-pencil calculations for simple cases and technology for more complicated cases (ST MA 1,4,5  1.4,3.4)(FR V.a, VIII.d, IX.6)

apply operations to matrices and complex numbers, using mental computation or paper-and-pencil calculations for simple cases and technology for more complicated cases (ST MA 1,4,5  1.4,3.4)(FR V.a, VIII.d, IX.6)
apply operations to vectors, using mental computation or paper-and-pencil calculations for simple cases and technology for more complicated cases (ST MA 1,4,5  1.4,3.4)(FR V.a, VIII.d, IX.6)
3.  Compute fluently and make reasonable estimates
A. Describe or represent mental strategies
recognize numerals up to 31 (ST MA _  1.6,1.10)
describe or represent  the mental strategy used to compute an addition problem (ST MA 1  3.4,4.1)(FR V.2.a)
describe or notate the mental strategy used to compute addition or subtraction of whole numbers, including 2-digit numbers (ST MA 1  3.4,4.1)(FR V.f)
represent a mental strategy used to compute a given multiplication problem (up to 2-digit by 2-digit multiple of) (ST MA 5  3.3)(FR IX.d)
describe a mental strategy used to compute a given division problem, where the quotient is a multiple of 10 and the divisor is a 1-digit number (e.g., 350 /7) (ST MA 1  1.4,3.3)(FR V.g)
B. Develop and demonstrate fluency
develop fluency with basic number relationships of addition and subtraction for sums up to 20 (ST MA.1  1.6)(FR V. 4.e)
demonstrate fluency with basic number relationships of addition and subtraction for sums up to 20 (ST MA.1  1.6)(FR V. 4.e)
develop fluency with basic number relationships (12 X 12) of multiplication and division (ST MA.1  1.6)(FR V. 4.e)
demonstrate  fluency with basic number relationships (12 X 12) of multiplication and division (ST MA.1  1.6)(FR V. 4.e)
C. Compute problems
apply and describe the strategy used to compute 2-digit addition or subtraction  problems (ST MA 5  1.6,1.10)(FR IX.e)
apply and describe the strategy used to compute up to a 3-digit addition or subtraction problem (ST MA 5  3.3,4.1)(FR IX.e)

apply and describe the strategy used to compute a given
  • multiplication problem up to a 2-digit by 2- digit
  • division problem up to a 3-digit by 1- digit
(ST MA 5 3.3,4.1)(FR IX.d)
apply and describe the strategy used to compute a given division problem up to a 3- digit by 2-digit (ST MA 1  3.3,4.1)(FR V.e)
add and subtract positive rational numbers (ST MA 1  1.10,3.3)(FR V.a)
multiply and divide positive rational numbers (ST MA 1  1.10,3.3)(FR V.a)
apply all operations on rational numbers (ST MA 1  1.10,3.3)(FR V.a)
apply all operations on real numbers (ST MA 5  1.10,3.3)(FR IX.a)
D. estimate and justify the results of addition and subtraction of whole numbers
estimate and justify the results of addition and subtraction of whole numbers (ST MA 1  3.3,4.1)(FR V.2.a)
estimate and justify the results of multiplication of whole numbers (ST MA 1  3.3,4.1)(FR V.f)
estimate and justify the results of division of whole numbers (ST MA 1  3.3,4.1)(FR V.f)
estimate and justify the results of addition and subtraction of positive rational numbers (ST MA 1  3.3.4.1)(FR V.e & h)
estimate and justify the results of multiplication and division of positive rational numbers (ST MA 1  3.3,4.1)(FR V.e & h)
estimate and justify the results of all operations on rational numbers (ST MA 1  3.3,4.1)(FR V.e & h)
judge the reasonableness of numerical computations and their results (ST MA 1  3.8)(FR V.a)
judge the reasonableness of numerical computations and their results (ST MA 1  3.8)(FR V.a)
judge the reasonableness of numerical computations and their results (ST MA 1  3.8)(FR V.a)
judge the reasonableness of numerical computations and their results (ST MA 1,4  5.8)(FR V.a, VIII.h)
E. Use proportional reasoning
solve problems using equivalent ratios (ST MA 1  3.3)(FR V.c)
solve problems involving proportions, such as scaling and finding equivalent ratios (ST MA 1  3.3)(FR V.c & f)
solve problems involving proportions, such as scaling and finding equivalent ratios (ST MA 1  3.3)(FR V.c & f)
solve problems involving proportions (ST MA 1,4  3.3)(FR V.a, VIII.e)
solve problems involving proportions (ST MA 1,4  3.3)(FR V.a, VIII.e)
solve problems involving proportions (ST MA 1,4  3.3)(FR V.a, VIII.e)
solve problems involving proportions (ST MA 1,4  3.3)(FR V.a, VIII.e)
1.  Understand patterns, relations and functions
A. Recognize and extend patterns
recognize or repeat sequences of sounds or shapes (ST MA 4  1.6) (FR VIII.a)
extend patterns of sound, shape, motion or a simple numeric pattern (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.a)
describe and extend simple numeric patterns and change from one representation to another (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.1.b)
extend geometric (shapes) and numeric patterns to find the next term (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.a)
describe geometric and numeric patterns (ST MA 4  1.6,4.1)(FR VIII.b)
analyze patterns using words, tables and graphs (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.4.b)
make and describe generalizations about geometric and numeric patterns (ST MA 4  1.6,4.1)(FR VIII.4.a)
B. Create and analyze patterns
create and continue patterns
describe how simple repeating patterns are generated (ST MA 4  1.6, 3.5)(FR VIII.a)
describe how simple growing patterns are generated (ST MA 4  1.6,3.5)(FR VIII.a)
represent patterns using words, tables or graphs (ST MA 4  3.6)(FR VIII.3.a)
represent and analyze patterns using words, tables and graphs (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.4.b)
represent and describe patterns with tables, graphs, pictures, symbolic rules or words (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.4.b, VIII.3)
analyze  patterns represented graphically or numerically using words or symbolic rules, including recursive notation (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.4.b)
generalize patterns represented graphically or numerically using words or symbolic rules, including recursive notation (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.4.b)
generalize patterns using explicitly or recursively defined functions (ST MA 4  1.6,3.5)(FR VIII.1.b)
generalize patterns using explicitly  or recursively defined functions (ST MA 4  1.6,3.5)(FR VIII.1.b)
generalize patterns using explicitly  or recursively defined functions (ST MA 4  1.6,3.5)(FR VIII.1.b)
generalize patterns using explicitly  or recursively defined functions (ST MA 4  1.6,3.5)(FR VIII.1.b)
C. Classify objects and representations
sort objects by size (ST MA 2  1.8)(FR VI.a)
classify objects by size or number (ST MA 2  1.8)(FR VI.a)
classify objects by size, number or other attributes (ST MA 2,6  1.8)(FR VI.a, X.c)
compare various forms of representations to identify a pattern (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.3.b)
compare and contrast various forms of representations of patterns (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.3.b)
compare and contrast various forms of representations  of patterns (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.3.b)
compare and contrast various forms of representations  of patterns (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.a & h)
compare and contrast various forms of representations  of patterns (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.a & h)
compare and contrast various forms of representations  of patterns (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.a & h)
compare and contrast various forms of representations  of patterns (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.a & h)
D. Identify and compare functions
identify functions as linear or nonlinear from a table or graph (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.b & c)
identify functions as linear or nonlinear from tables, graphs or equations (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.b & c)
compare properties of linear functions between or among tables, graphs and equations (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.b & c)
understand and compare the properties of linear and exponential functions (include intercepts) (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.b & c)
understand and compare the properties of linear, exponential and quadratic functions (include domain and range) (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.b & c)
understand and compare the properties of linear, quadratic, exponential, logarithmic and rational functions (include asymptotes) (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.b & c)
understand and compare the properties of exponential, polynomial, rational, logarithmic, and periodic functions (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.4.h)
E. Describe the effects of parameter changes
describe the effects of parameter changes on linear functions (ST MA 4  1.6,4.1)(FR VIII.i)
describe the effects of parameter changes on quadratic and exponential functions (ST MA 4  1.6,4.1)(FR VIII.i)
describe the effects of parameter changes on logarithmic and exponential functions (ST MA 4  1.6,4.1)(FR VIII.i)
describe the effects of parameter changes on polynomial and periodic function (ST MA 4  1.6,4.1)(FR VIII.i)
2.  Represent and analyze mathematical situations and structures using algebraic symbols
A. Represent mathematical situations
represent a mathematical situation as an expression or number sentence (ST MA 4  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII.2.b, VIII.5.c)
represent a mathematical situation as an expression or number sentence (ST MA 4  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII.2.b, VIII.5.c)
represent a mathematical situation as an expression or number sentence (ST MA 4  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII.2.b)
represent a mathematical situation as an expression or number sentence (ST MA 4  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII.2.b)
represent a mathematical situation as an expression or number sentence using a letter or symbol  (ST MA 4  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII.2.e)
use variables to represent unknown quantities in expressions (ST MA 4  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII 2 e)
use variables to represent unknown quantities in equations and inequalities (ST MA 4  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII.2.e)
use symbolic algebra to represent and solve problems that involve linear relationships, including recursive relationships (ST MA 4  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII.2.e)
use symbolic algebra to represent and solve problems that involve linear relationships, including  absolute value and recursive relationships (ST MA 4,6  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII.c & d, X.h)
use symbolic algebra to represent and solve problems that involve quadratic relationships, including recursive relationships (ST MA 4,6  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII.c & d, X.h)
use symbolic algebra to represent and solve problems that involve exponential and logarithmic relationships, including recursive and parametric relationships (ST MA 4,6  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII.c & d, X.h)
use symbolic algebra to represent and solve problems that involve periodic relationships, including recursive and parametric relationships (ST MA 4,6  1.6,3.1)(FR VIII.c & d, X.h)
B. Describe and use mathematical manipulation
investigate  commutative principle with whole numbers(ST MA 5  3.1)(FR IX.1)
apply the commutative property to addition of whole numbers (ST MA 5  3.1)(FR IX.1)
apply the commutative property of multiplication to whole numbers (ST MA 5  3.1)(FR IX.1)
apply the distributive and associative properties to whole numbers (ST MA 5  3.1)(FR IX.1)
recognize equivalent forms for simple algebraic expressions (associative, distributive  properties) (ST MA 5  3.6)(FR IX.1)
generate equivalent forms for simple algebraic expressions (ST MA 4  3.6)(FR VIII.a)
generate equivalent forms for linear expressions (ST MA 4  3.6)(FR VIII.a)
describe and use algebraic manipulations, including factoring and rules of integer exponents (ST MA 4  3.1,4.1)(FR VIII.a & d)
describe and use algebraic manipulations, including factoring and rules of integer exponents (ST MA 4  3.1,4.1)(FR VIII.a & d)
describe and use algebraic manipulations, including inverse of functions, composition of functions and rules of exponents (ST MA 4  3.1,4.1)(FR VIII.a & d & g)
describe and use algebraic manipulations, including inverse of functions, composition of functions (ST MA 4  3.1,4.1)(FR VIII.a & d & g)
C. Utilize equivalent forms
use and solve equivalent forms of equations and inequalities (linear) (ST MA 4  1.6,3.4)(FR VIII.d & e)
use and solve equivalent forms of equations and  inequalities (piece-wise and quadratic) (ST MA 4  1.6,3.4)(FR VIII.d)
use and solve equivalent forms of equations and inequalities (exponential, logarithmic and rational) (ST MA 4  1.6,3.4)(FR VIII.d)
use and solve equivalent forms of equations and  inequalities (polynomial and trigonometric) (ST MA 4  1.6,3.4)(FR VIII.e & h)
D. Utilize systems
use and solve systems of linear equations with 2 variables (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.b & d)
use and solve systems of linear equations or inequalities with 2 variables (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.b & d)
use and solve systems of linear and quadratic equations or inequalities with 2 variables (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.b & d)
use and solve systems of equations or inequalities (ST MA 4  1.6)(FR VIII.b & d)
3.  Use mathematical models to represent and understand quantitative relationships
A. Use mathematical models
model situations that involve whole numbers, using pictures, objects or symbols (ST MA 1,4  1.6,3.6)(FR V.c, VIII.1)
model situations that involve the addition of whole numbers, using pictures, objects or symbols (ST MA 1,4  1.6,3.6)(FR V.c, VIII.1)
model situations that involve addition and subtraction of whole numbers, using pictures, objects or symbols (ST MA 1,4  1.6,3.6)(FR V.c, VIII.1)
model problem situations, including multiplication with objects or drawings (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.I)
model problem situations, using representations such as graphs, tables or number sentences (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.I)
model problem situations and draw conclusions, using representations such as graphs, tables or number sentence (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.b)
model and solve problems, using multiple representations such as graphs, tables, expressions and  equations (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.b)
model and solve problems, using multiple representations such as graphs, tables, expressions, equations or inequalities (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.b)
model and solve problems, using multiple representations such as graphs, tables, equations or inequalities (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.b)
identify quantitative relationships and determine the type(s) of functions that might model the situation to solve the problem (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.c)
identify quantitative relationships and determine the type(s) of functions that might model the situation to solve the problem (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.c)
identify quantitative relationships and determine the type(s) of functions that might model the situation to solve the problem (including recursive forms) (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.c & h)
identify quantitative relationships and determine the type(s) of functions that might model the situation to solve the problem (including recursive forms) (ST MA 4  1.6,3.6)(FR VIII.c & h)
4.  Analyze change in various contexts
A. Analyze change
describe qualitative change, such as students growing taller (ST MA 4  4.1)(FR VIII.b)
describe quantitative change, such as students growing two inches in a year (ST MA 4  4.1)(FR VIII.b)
describe mathematical relationships in terms of constant rates of change (ST MA 4  4.1)(FR VIII.c)
identify, model and describe situations with constant or varying rates of change (ST MA 4  1.6,4.1)(FR VIII.c)
compare situations with constant or varying rates of change (ST MA 2,4  1.6,4.1)(FR VI I, VIII.c)
compare situations with constant or varying rates of change (ST MA 2,4  1.6,4.1)(FR VI I, VIII.c)
analyze the nature of changes (including slope and intercepts) in quantities in linear relationships (ST MA 2,4  1.6,4.1)(FR VI.I, VIII.c)
analyze linear functions by investigating rates of change and intercepts (ST MA 4  1.6,4.1)(FR VIII.a & c)
analyze quadratic  functions by investigating rates of change, intercepts and zeros (ST MA 4  1.6,4.1)(FR VIII.a & c)
analyze exponential and logarithmic  functions by investigating rates of change, intercepts and asymptotes (ST MA 4  1.6,4.1)(FR VIII.a & c)
analyze rational, polynomial and periodic functions by investigating rates of change, intercepts and asymptotes (ST MA 4  1.6,4.1)(FR VIII.h & g)
1.  Analyze characteristics and properties of two- and three-dimensional geometric shapes and develop mathematical arguments about geometric relationships
A. Describe and use geometric relationships
sort 2- and 3-dimensional shapes using physical models (circle, rectangle, triangle, sphere, rectangular prism, cylinder, pyramid) (ST MA 2  1.6)(FR VI.2)
recognize and name 2- and 3-dimensional shapes using physical models (circle, triangle, trapezoid, rectangle, rhombus, sphere, rectangular prism, cylinder, pyramid) (ST MA 2  1.6,1.10)(FR VI.2.a)
describe attributes and parts of 2- and 3-dimensional shapes (circle, triangle, trapezoid, rectangle, rhombus, sphere, rectangular prism, cylinder, pyramid (ST MA 2  1.6,1.10)(FR VI.2.a)
compare 2- and 3-dimensional shapes by describing their attributes (circle, rectangle, rhombus, trapezoid,  triangle, rectangular prism, cylinder, pyramid and sphere) (ST MA 2  1.6,1.10)(FR VI.2.c)
identify and describe the attributes of 2- and 3-dimensional shapes  (prisms, cones, parallelism, perpendicularity) (ST MA 2  1.6,1.10)(FR VI.2.a)
analyze 2- and 3-dimensional  shapes by describing the attributes (ST MA 2  1.5,4.1)(FR VI.2)
identify the properties of 1- 2- and 3- dimensional  shapes using the appropriate geometric vocabulary (ST MA 2  1.10,3.3)(FR VI.2.a)
classify 2- and 3-dimensional shapes based on their properties (ST MA 2  3.6)(FR VI.2.a)

describe, classify and generalize relationships between and among types of a) 2-dimensional objects and b) 3- dimensional objects using their defining properties including
  • Pythagorean Theorem
  • cross-section of a 3-dimensional object results in what 2-dimensional shape
solve problems involving angle relationships (supplementary, complementary angles) and Pythagorean Theorem (ST MA 2  1.6)(FR VI.c)
use inductive and deductive reasoning to establish the validity of geometric conjectures, proved theorems and critique arguments made by others (ST MA 2  3.5)(FR VI.d)
use trigonometric relationships with right triangles to determine lengths and angle measures (ST MA 2  1.6,1.10)(FR VI.l)
use trigonometric relationships to determine lengths and angle measures in all types of triangles (ST MA 2  1.6,1.10)(FR VI.l)
B. Apply geometric relationships
describe relationships between the corresponding angles and the length of corresponding sides of similar triangles (whole number scale factors) (ST MA 2  1.6)(FR VI.c)
describe relationships between corresponding sides, corresponding angles and corresponding perimeters of similar polygons (ST MA 2  1.6)(FR VI.c)
apply relationships between corresponding sides and corresponding areas of similar polygons to solve problems (ST MA 2 1.6,3.6)(FR VI.c)
apply geometric properties and relationships, such as similarity, to solve multi-step problems in 2 dimensions (ST MA 2  3.6)(FR VI.c)
apply relationships among surface areas and among volumes of similar objects (ST MA 2  3.6)(FR VI.c & i)
determine the effect on surface area or volume of changing one measurement (ST MA 2  3.5)(FR VI.i)
C. Compose and decompose shapes
predict the results of putting together or taking apart 2- and 3- dimensional shapes (ST MA 2  1.6,4.1)(FR VI.2.b)
describe the results of subdividing, combining and transforming shapes (ST MA 2  1.6,4.1)(FR VI.b)
predict and justify the results of subdividing, combining and transforming shapes (ST MA 2  1.6,4.1)(FR VI.b)
2.  Specify locations and describe spatial relationships using coordinate geometry and other representational systems
A. Use coordinate systems
describe, name and interpret relative positions in space (above, below, front, behind) (ST MA 2  3.3,4.1)(FR VI.4.i)
describe, name and interpret relative positions in space (left, right) (ST MA 2  3.3,4.1)(FR VI.4.i)
find and name locations with simple relationships on a map (coordinate system) (ST MA 2  3.3,4.1)(FR VI.4.i)
describe location using common language and geometric vocabulary (forward, back, left, right, north, south, east, west) (ST MA 2  3.3,4.1)(FR VI.4.i)
describe movement using common language and geometric vocabulary (forward, back, left, right, north, south, east, west) (ST MA 2  3.3,4.1)(FR VI.4.i)
use coordinate systems to specify locations, describe paths and find the distance between points along horizontal and vertical lines (ST MA 2  1.6,1.8)(FR VI.e)
use coordinate geometry to construct geometric shapes  (ST MA 2  1.6,1.8)(FR VI.a)
given ordered pairs, identify geometric shapes in the coordinate plane using their properties (ST MA 2  1.6,1.8)(FR VI.c)
use coordinate geometry to analyze properties of right triangles and quadrilaterals (ST MA 2  3.6)(FR VI.f)
solve problems related to 2- dimensional objects by finding the distance on a Cartesian plane (ST MA 2  3.2)(FR VI.f)
make conjectures and solve problems involving 2-dimensional objects represented with Cartesian coordinates (ST MA 2  3.6,4.1)(FR VI.f)
